title.en: Advanced Introduction to the Philosophy of Mind and Language

description.en: The course covers topics about the mind of contemporary and future relevance, such as artificial consciousness, superintelligence, cyborgs, virtual reality, mind uploading, and transhumanism. It prepares students to think critically about these challenges.
description.et: Õppeaine käsitleb vaimufilosoofia tänaseid ja tuleviku küsimusi nagu tehisteadvus, superintellekt, küborgid, virtuaalreaalsus, vaimu üleslaadimine ja transhumanism. Aine valmistab osalejaid ette selliste probleemide üle kriitiliselt mõtlema.

objectives.en: This course is designed for students interested in philosophical questions concerning the rapid development of artificial intelligence (AI) and its impact on the human mind today and in the future.  This course aims to provide students with an understanding of the philosophical issues linked to developments in AI technology. We will dive into the future of artificial and human minds to investigate the metaphysical, ethical, and social implications of AI development. By exploring various topics, such as superintelligence, artificial consciousness, mind uploading, virtual reality, transhumanism, cyborgs, and human-robot relationships, students practice their analysis, critical thinking, and communication skills.
objectives.et: Õppeaine on mõeldud üliõpilastele, keda huvitavad filosoofilised küsimused seoses tehisintellekti (AI) kiire arengu ja selle mõjuga inimvaimule tänapäeval ja tulevikus. Õppeaine eesmärk on aidata üliõpilastel mõista AI arenguga seotud filosoofilisi probleeme. Süüvime tehis- ja inimmõistuse tulevikku, et uurida tehisintellekti arendamise metafüüsilisi, eetilisi ja sotsiaalseid tagajärgi. Uurides erinevaid teemasid nagu superintellekt, tehisteadvus, vaimu üleslaadimine, virtuaalreaalsus, transhumanism, küborgid ning inimese ja roboti suhted, harjutavad üliõpilased oma analüüsi-, kriitilise mõtlemise ja suhtlemisoskusi.

learning_outcomes.en: After having successfully completed the course, the student:
* is capable of identifying and debating key philosophical issues related to the rapid development of artificial intelligence and its impact on the concept of mind;
learning_outcomes.et: * võimeline tuvastama filosoofilisi võtmeküsimusi, mis on seotud tehisintellekti kiire arengu ja selle mõjuga vaimu mõistele, ja nende üle arutlema;

learning_outcomes.en: * has enhanced their philosophy-specific written and oral communication and argumentation skills.
learning_outcomes.et: * arendanud oma filosoofia-spetsiifilist kirjutamisoskust ning suulise suhtlemise ja argumenteerimise oskusi.

learning_outcomes.en: * has explored issues related to the transformation of the concept of mind, human identity, and agency in the age of AI;
learning_outcomes.et: * uurinud küsimusi, mis on seotud vaimu, isikusamasuse ja toimijalisuse mõiste muutumisega tehisintellekti ajastul;

learning_outcomes.en: * has applied critical thinking to real-world challenges, anticipating future developments of AI and their broader impacts on humanity;
learning_outcomes.et: * rakendanud kriitilist mõtlemist päriselu väljakutsete lahendamisel, ennetades tehisintellekti edasisi arenguid ja nende laiemat mõju inimkonnale;

learning_outcomes.en: * has formulated and defended some solutions to philosophical problems that need to be addressed in order to make progress on real-world challenges related to developments in AI technology;
learning_outcomes.et: * sõnastanud ja kaitsnud lahendusi filosoofilistele probleemidele, millega tuleb tegeleda, et olla edukas tehisintellekti arenguga seotud päriselu väljakutsete lahendamisel;

learning_outcomes.en: * has practiced discussing and assessing the ethical and societal implications of AI on future human cognition and society, fostering responsible perspectives.
learning_outcomes.et: * arutlenud tehisintellekti eetiliste ja ühiskondlike mõjude üle inimese tunnetusele ja ühiskonnale, edendades seejuures vastutustundlikku vaatevinklit.

notes.et:
Prerequisite courses:
* Philosophy MA students must have completed the Start module courses of the Philosophy MA before they can take this course. 
* For everyone else, the course "Advanced Introduction to the Philosophy of Mind and Language" from the Start module in the Philosophy in Practice MA
* Recommended: BA-level Philosophy of Mind course FLFI.04.060.

independent_work.et:
* Reading seminar texts.
* Preparing for classroom discussion.
* Group work with fellow students.
* Writing a reflective exercise.

description.et:
1. Forum participation (linked to the capacity of identifying key philosophical issues related to AI)
Before each seminar, students are required to post two questions related to the seminar's text and respond to two questions posed by their peers.
Non-differentiated assessment.

2. Leading Classroom Discussion (linked to philosophy-specific oral communication skills)
Students take turns leading the classroom discussion on assigned topics either individually or in pairs.
Non-differentiated assessment.

3. Group Work (linked to philosophy-specific writing, argumentation and communication skills) 
Groups of students investigate one topic in depth by engaging with additional reading material and discussing it amongst themselves. They prepare a short presentation on their findings. This collaborative effort is assessed for credit (differentiated).
60% of overall grade.

4. Personal Reflection (linked to philosophy-specific writing and argumentation skills and the capacity to identify philosophical issues)
Students write a reflection of 3-4 pages on how some topic covered in the course relates to their personal experiences with AI or impacts their lives. This reflective exercise is included in the assessment (differentiated).
40% of overall grade.

grade_preconditions.et: No more than three seminars can be missed. If a student misses the seminar, they need to do write a short analysis of the seminar text.

grade_evaluation.et:
Group work 60%, personal reflection 40% of overall grade.

Grade boundaries: 
A = 90-100%
B = 80-89%
C = 70-79%
D = 60-69%
E = 50-59%
F = less than 50%

assessment_scale.et: Eristav (A, B, C, D, E, F, mi)
assessment_scale.en: differentiated (A, B, C, D, E, F, not present)

description.et:
2. Seminar: SUPERINTELLIGENCE
Chalmers, David J. (2016). The Singularity. In Susan Schneider (ed.), Science Fiction and Philosophy: From Time Travel to Superintelligence. Hoboken, NJ: Wiley. pp. 171-224.
Bostrom, Nick (2006). How Long Before Superintelligence? Linguistic and Philosophical Investigations, Vol. 5, No. 1, pp. 11-30.
Kurzweil, Ray (2005). The Impact [Excerpt]. In R. Kurzweil, The Singularity is Near. London: Duckworth, pp. 299-330.

3. Seminar: ARTIFICIAL CONSCIOUSNESS
Dennett, Daniel C. (1997). Consciousness in Human and Robot Minds. In M. Ito, Y. Miyashita, Edmund T. Rolls (eds.), Cognition, Computation and Consciousness. Oxford University Press, 17-29.
Schneider, Susan (2020). How to Catch an AI Zombie: Testing for Consciousness in Machines, in S. Matthew Liao (ed.), Ethics of Artificial Intelligence. New York: Oxford University Press.

4. Seminar: MIND UPLOADING
Chalmers, David J. (2014). Uploading: A Philosophical Analysis. In Russell Blackford, Damien Broderick (eds.), Intelligence Unbound. Chichester, UK: Wiley. pp. 102-118.
Corabi, Joseph & Schneider, Susan (2014). If You Upload, Will You Survive? In Russell Blackford, Damien Broderick (eds.), Intelligence Unbound. Chichester, UK: Wiley. pp. 131-145.

5. Seminar: VIRTUAL REALITY
Bostrom, Nick (2003). Are We Living in a Computer Simulation? Philosophical Quarterly 53 (211):243-255.
Chalmers, David J. (2005). The matrix as metaphysics. In Christopher Grau (ed.), Philosophers Explore the Matrix. Oxford University Press. Reprinted in Susan Schneider (ed.), Science Fiction and Philosophy: From Time Travel to Superintelligence. Hoboken, NJ: Wiley. pp. 35-54.

6. Seminar: VIRTUAL REALITY
Watching the episode of "San Junipero" (Black Mirror) + discussion.

7. Seminar: TRANSHUMANISM
https://www.humanityplus.org/
Schneider, Susan. (2009). Future Minds: Transhumanism, Cognitive Enhancement and the Nature of Persons, In The Penn Center Guide to Bioethics (pp. 844-856), Vardit Ravitsky, Autumn Fiester and Arthur L. Caplan (eds.). Springer.
Fuller, Steve (2018). Is the Future 'Human', 'Posthuman' or 'Transhuman'? In Frontiers of Global Sociology: Research Perspectives for the 21st Century, Markus S. Schulz (ed), Berlin: ISA Research, 62-68.

8. Seminar: CYBORGS
Clark, Andy. (2003). Cyborgs Unplugged. In Andy Clark, Natural Born Cyborgs: Minds, Technologies, and the Future of Human Intelligence. Oxford, pp. 13-34.
Turner, Cody & Schneider, Susan (2020). Could You Merge With AI? Reflections on the Singularity and Radical Brain Enhancement. In Markus Dirk Dubber, Frank Pasquale & Sunit Das (eds.), The Oxford Handbook of Ethics of AI. Oxford University Press. pp. 307-325.

9. Seminar: HUMAN-ROBOT RELATIONSHIPS
Nyholm, S. (2020). Ch. "Robotic relationships" from Humans and Robots: Ethics, Agency, and Anthropomorphism. Rowman & Littlefield Publishers.

10. Seminar: HUMAN-ROBOT RELATIONSHIPS
Watching the episode of "Be right back" (Black Mirror) + discussion.

11. Seminar: SOCIAL ROBOTS
Sweeney, P. (2021). A fictional dualism model of social robots. Ethics and Information Technology, 23, 465-472. https://doi.org/10.1007/s10676-021-09589-9
Sharkey, N., & Sharkey, A. (2010). The crying shame of robot nannies: An ethical appraisal. Interaction Studies, 11(2), 161-190. https://doi.org/10.1075/is.11.2.01sha 
Bryson, J. J. (2010). Why robot nannies probably won't do much psychological damage. Interaction Studies, 11(2), 196-200. https://doi.org/10.1075/is.11.2.03bry

audience.et: Philosophy MA students, MA students of philosophy, students from all fields who have taken “Advanced Introduction to the Philosophy of Mind and Language”
